												If 'Charm' was a new word for 2015 then this game would have invented it.


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



It's full of cool twist and is a charm to behold. It looks amazing and plays like a dream. If a puzzle game ever dared to venture outside-the-box, then this is what you would get. Botanicula is a humor-filled adventure game created by the makers of award-winning Machinarium, studio Amanita Design and Czech band DVA. You control 5 little tree creatures and set out on a journey to save the last seed from their home tree which is infested by evil parasites. - Highly Recommended!

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 14
												This game is very simple. Its only involves clicking the right places, or tugging.This game is insanely hard, even unfair towards the end. Clicks are necessary at the right time in the right window at the right place. There is no help. There is no dialogue, except for some noises and more or less hidden signs. You didn't get them? Too bad, your fault. In later chapters, there is a multitude of screens, sometimes a maze, that you have to go through in the right order - with puzzles that sometimes are less than counterintuitive.Graphics, or should I say "audiovisual presentations" are not to everyone's taste. It's clearly "art". Deal with that.If you want to immerse in this story, go ahead. It's fun. I, for my part, followed the walkthrough and enjoyed a visual novel - without the fuss and the frustration of going through dozens of screens checking if I'd overlooked something. Like that, I actually enjoyed playing it - but you shouldn't expect more than 2-3 hours, anyway.Oh, and I forgot to mention: There is a "Full Screen" Option to play this game. Which means that there is a large black screen with the game running in its native resolution in the middle. Which was kind of... influencing the whole experience in a negative way, because I was playing in 3440x1440. Which meant LOTS of black space. Talk about using the mouse pointer in an exact way...

number of helpful: 6 of 23 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Unique characters and world can't save point-and-click adventure Botanicula from endless backtracking and frustrating puzzles. The word "puzzles" is generous; Most gameplay involves clicking on every creature in the game until they spit out a key. The main characters give off a cutesy feel, but their constant squeaks and giggling language eventually grates. Esthetically unique but unable to decide if it wants to be silly or creepy. The result is creepy... and unsettling. ACHIEVEMENTS: If you do attempt this game because it's already in your Steam library from a Humble Bundle you bought 3 years ago, the achievements are easy but at the same time frustrating because is game is so slow paced. The achievements are largely clicking on every creature in the whole game. Look it up before proceeding if your main interest is Achievements.

number of helpful: 8 of 30 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												I really, really wanted to like this game. However, it was just too abstract for my taste. Don't get me wrong, there are some interesting parts, and the graphics and artwork are pretty neat. Just be forewarned that this is definitely not your typical point and click game. So if you're looking for an epic adventure, this isn't the game for you. Most of the puzzles were pretty self-explanatory, but there were a few tricky ones (which is OK, you don't want them all to be easy!). It's also very short (which was OK for me because I just wanted to finish it and be done with it). Definitely not a terrible game, but overall, I would not recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Meh. I was keen to try this, having played Machinarium. This is no one in the same league. The game just feel unimmersive and unfocused. I felt I was endlessly clicking to uncover what elements responded to click. The puzzles were annoying more than enjoyable. The flow seems linear and forced, there weren't creative/clever ways to address a challenge, you had to do exactly what the designer wanted you to -- which in some cases was click on an element 4 times and then click on something else, but you had no way of knowing you had to click 4 times because the first 3 clicks didn't do anything different or show a progression building to another click. Ugh. I forced myself to keep playing as it was highly rated and I felt I wasn't getting something. Nope. Just not my thing.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2013
												While Amanita Designs have had an incredibly impressive track-record in making unique and visually pleasant games, with their almost trademark handdrawn backgrounds and no-words dialogues, they seem to have all been chowing down a few too many "funki fungi" while whipping up this one. Instead of thinking your way through the game, like you did in Machinarium, you basically just click random crap until other random crap appears/happens/goes away/changes screens. While the visuals are still present, the musical style from their previous, oh-so-funky title Machinarium, is sadly gone too. Bottom line, boys? Not good. At all. 3.3/10

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I haven't smoked weed in, like, twelve years. The last time I chiefed that keef I was at a party at some DJ's house and he was handing out joints to everyone because I guess that's how DJ's win friends and influence people. I hesitated, but being that everyone else was doing it and I had no real reason not to, I smoked the one he gave to me. Weed is really stong these days. I don't know if they still grow the dirt weed that I used to smoke in high school, but back in the day I could do bong rips until the sun went down and not really be any worse off, just really hungry and couch-locked. That joint the dude gave me - that one joint - had me laid out on the couch thinking that my heart was going to explode and wishing I had never gone to that party in the first place. After we all smoked our joints the DJ announced that it was time for a cigarette break and motioned us all to step outside because for some reason weed was ok to smoke  indoors, but tobacco was not. So I stood up to follow everyone outside and as soon as I got up, my vision went black and I passed out on the floor. Just, like, crumpled and fell down. No one cared. Absolutely no one gave a♥♥♥♥♥♥ Nobody ran to my side to see if I was okay, no one rolled me over to make sure I wouldn't vomit into my airway. Nothing. I came to a couple minutes later when everyone had finished smoking and these girls were just walking over me to get back inside and claim a spot in the comfortable chairs.A real friend - no, any decent human being - would have the compassion to check on the guy who just fell down and went unresponsive. And as unpleasant as that evening was, at least it taught me not to hang out with Ken and his DJ friend anymore.SO, this game may look cool, and have pretty colors and seem slighly reminiscent of Samorost, but the similarity ends there. It's not really that fun, and I would be remiss if I let you click that buy button. The puzzles are okay, I guess, but the more I played this pile, the more I found myself wishing I was playing Samorost.

Posted: September 18, 2012
												I'm definitely far from being experienced in the adventure game genre, but of the few titles which I have experienced, this one is easily the most well-rounded, unique, and forward-thinking of the bunch.  All of the game's elements -- the music, art, animations, sound effects, puzzles, and controls -- fit together perfectly.  It's that rare treat of an experimental title which is so well thought out and executed that it changes your expectations for its genre.  It's accessible, satisfying, and beautiful.  Try it out sometime.

Posted: June 10, 2014
												Botanicula is an artistic, symbolic game.  Its artists really embraces a new medium in storytelling.  Not only is it a video game it feels like an interactive story book that goes deep within the issues that surrounds us today.  The lessons almost seeming to transend beyond the digital world so that you can apply them to everyday life on the outside.Plus it's something to help you wind down, so, it works on multiple levels.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game is pure joy in software form. It's beautiful, and the sound design is amazing. There are some annoying sequences and it is very much a linear point and click, but it definitely makes up for its negatives tenfold. If you have any interest in the genre, you owe it to yourself to pick Botanicula up and give it a try!

Posted: June 24, 2014
												I had this game a while back before owning it on steam. Very interesting game. I love the visuals. Definitely a sense of beauty in this game. Its even pretty funny at times. The story is simple yet interesting. You play as a group of little plant guys and some evil thing is sucking the life out of the world so you need to stop it. The puzzles were challenging enough that i had to sit and think for a bit but not challenging to the point where i needed to look up guides on the internet like with their other game, Machinarium (another great game by the way.)In short, if youre looking for something different and wonderful than pick this guy up. Enjoy it. I was thoroughly pleased with it and even teared up a little in the end. As far as point and click puzzle games go i  would give the a solid 10/10.

Posted: May 7, 2012
												After finishing this game, I wanted to run out and plant a tree.  Seriously, though, this game is absolutely beautiful.  The character design is original and adorable.  The soundtrack and sound effects -- all done by the two people who make up DVA -- are perfect, and add to the naturalistic atmosphere of the game wonderfully.  The setting itself is fantastic and imaginative, with its little secrets and delights to discover.  You cannot imagine my reaction when the giant turtle revealed itself (you know the part if you've seen it), or when the lightning bugs land on the vines in the area under the frogs and crabs (again, you'll know the part when you see it).  The game also balances humor and terror very nicely.  The dream sequences are some of the creepiest game scenes I've ever seen, and the Zlos themselves are their own lovely brand of horror.  In short, this game was worth the price I paid for it.  20/10, would play again.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												Botanicula is the strangest game I have ever played. I say that with pretty full confidence in my gaming memory. Don’t get me wrong, strange does not by any stretch mean bad. In fact, Botanicula is one of the best games, if not the best, that I have played all year. I love nearly everything about it, down to the absolute simplicity of the story. It’s a tale that’s been done many times before, but never quite like this.A fantastic tree is the home for many wonderful creatures. Magical life seeds grow from every limb… seeds that allow beings on the tree to live in peace and harmony. One day, a dark entity, one greatly resembling a dark spider, comes and begins to ingest all of the seeds, drawing away all of the life and happiness that the tree houses. It is up to a small group of nuts, seeds, and feathers (yes, you heard me right) to save their home from this evil that has fallen upon them.It’s an odd take on a classic story. Botanicula takes a step in a direction most games won’t take. They’ve assigned the main roles of their tale to a bunch on inanimate, absolutely regular objects that live in a world of what I can only describe as magic. When was the last time you saw a game that had a feather diving in and out of holes to solve puzzles? It’s a daring move… or just weird, depending on how you view it. It’s a pleasure to play something that’s different, even from most indie games.Botanicula is a point-and-click adventure game. This is a genre in which I am not very well versed. I’m ashamed to admit that I haven’t played some of the classics, like King’s Quest. Botanicula is more streamlined than traditional point-and-clicks, but that isn’t a bad thing. There was only one or two points in which I truly couldn’t figure out what to do, but sitting there for an hour stuck on one puzzle never got overly frustrating. I never felt like the game was calling me out for being an idiot. If I couldn’t figure out a puzzle and I needed to sit there and solve it without moving, the game wouldn’t do any unnecessary movements or sounds reminding me that I need to move on. I appreciated that more than I thought I would.Botanicula’s puzzles are a mixture of movement-based solving games, exploration, and fetch quests. Yeah, I know, a game having good fetch quests? Well, but that’s what the genre of point-and-clicks are partially about. I mean, a lot of what they’re about are trying to solve what piece of which goes where. And, if you go back even farther, they are also “how the hell do I pick up this god-forsaken crowbar?” Botanicula doesn’t do that. It doesn’t hold your hand or give you hints, but it gives you as much time as you need to solve a puzzle. You can’t die, you can only be knocked part of the way back. It’s a nice touch.Exploration is one of the best things about Botanicula. Some areas are completely pointless to the actual puzzle or storyline, but they’re added just so you can experience the beauty that this game truly has to offer. As you look around the tree, you’ll find different creatures and beings that you can interact with. Some of these creatures will give you cards or a pretty display of some kind. Adding the collectable cards into the game gives meandering a purpose, beyond just being a wonderful and rather relaxing pleasure.I usually save the art design and music for last when I’m in a review, but I simply can’t avoid talking about it any longer. Everything about this game is flooring. Everything. From the silly little sound effects down to the horror that the environment gives you in the later levels. With the exception of Bastion and Badland, I’ve yet to see a game with this quality of art this year.The music is just indescribable. Really, it’s quite difficult to do. Everything about it gives off a mystic sense, but none of it seems to fit in any one genre. It all sounds like it comes from the same source, which is excellently implemented, as the tree is the centerpiece for the entire game. The music will make you feel what you need to. If you need to feel accomplished in this scene, you will. If you need to feel terrified, you will. If you need to have a feeling of foreboding, believe me, you will. It’s one of the best soundtracks in any game I’ve ever played. Ever.The game doesn’t have any real talking in it, and I’m 100% okay with that. Dialogue would add absolutely nothing to the game. The story will make you feel for the characters without the use of speech. Sure, there is some humming, or quiet gibberish, or squeals and gasps, but they’re varied and far between. They only happen when they need to. There is no fat in this game. All of it is cut out. You only get what you need; what you deserve.The sound effects are just as appropriate as the music, clearly. The group you play as has their own sounds that they make, generally as a group. The other characters in the game all make different noises as well, and each one seems to fit the situation perfectly. Some of the sound effects are annoying, but that’s not a bad thing. Except for when you’re stuck on a puzzle in which you have to hear an annoying sound over and over and over.Visual art is arguably the best part of the game. It’s beautiful. It’s also quite psychedelic. Those two seem to go hand in hand when it comes to good games. Every area on the tree is fitting to the characters in it, and everything feels… right. It’s hard to explain, really. I suppose it’s one of those things that you just need to experience for yourself.The group with which you play all have different abilities that you can use at certain points, but it’s very rare you do so. This is one of my few complaints with this game. You’re playing as a group of five, but you only use each character’s special properties once or twice. At the end of the game (spoilers) you have to rescue four of the five characters from the dark spider. I would care a lot more about saving them if I felt like each of them had their own personality, and I didn’t really feel that.Speaking of the giant spiders, they are the perfect antagonist for a game like this. They’re scary, but not scary in the same sense that we humans would find terrifying. Instead they make the characters (and, by proxy, you) feel nervous and uneasy about what they are and why they’re doing what they are. They are silent as well. It’s never explained why the spiders are trying to engulf the tree with darkness, but I think that’s one of the beauties of this game.In case I haven’t made it clear already, Botanicula doesn’t make much sense. It doesn’t have a pulling backstory like Bastion or a continuous reactionary setting like Badland, but it makes a perfect balance with these games. Badland makes a perfect quick and easy yet puzzling reaction game. Bastion makes you cry and seriously feel for the characters within it, as you help them fight their way back home. Botanicula fills the gap as it sets you on an adventure that you can solve at your own pace, a way to save your home from an evil that’s never truly explained.I love the fact that Botanicula doesn’t explain everything. It makes the experience so much more innocent. Everything about it makes you want to keep playing, makes you want to explore the homes of hundreds of creatures, makes you want to save your home from a masked villain. Botanicula proves that you don’t need a huge budget to make a game that is truly fantastic. Trying to choose the game of the year this year is going to be damned near impossible, because Botanicula gets a96/100- NJIf you want to read more about Botanicula, visit our websitetheoblivianstudios.com

												If you enjoy point-and-click puzzle/adventure games and/or other games from Amanita Designs, you need to own this game -now-. The artwork is lush, the soundtrack is enjoyable and incredibly layered, and despite no written or spoken dialogue (par for the course for Amanita games), you get an in-depth sense of character from both the protagonists and the enemies through clever animation and sound effects. Some of the puzzles can be very devious and you'll find yourself clicking -everything- in hopes of collecting another card. 												A clever game with cute graphics and a fun storyline. Posted: May 7, 2012
												Botanicula is a short point and click adventure game from the developers of Machinarium and Samorost 1 and 2, Amanita Design. The game lasts about six to seven hours (getting all achievements and such), all of which are amazing. Every interaction is full of life, emotion, and uniqueness - resulting in characters with more personality than ones in most AAA games. The characters and story rival those, if not exceed, of Machinarium's. Only "flaw" with the game is there are no puzzles or much challenge, and thus no real gameplay. This takes away any real replay value.Only thing Botanicula can offer is character. Fortunately that's all you really need with this game.Edit: I take back the AAA dig - it's unfair. This game has more personality than a lot of indie games too.

Posted: January 4, 2013
												Oh noes, it's over already :(I should have picked this one up immediately when it came out; the design told me so. The reason I didn't - I guess - was (apart from me hoping it would be in an indie bundle) that I couldn't imagine how gameplay would fit into this when I saw the trailer. And to be honest, the game doesn't exactly score with its gameplay mechanics; they have something browser-gamerish, even almost dilettant about them. But really, I couldn't care less. Because no game since... actually I cannot even think of any right now that ensorcelled (does that word really exist? O_o) me in such a way as this one (of course some other games à la Final Fantasy VII captivated me in very different ways). How does this game manage to do this? With its apparant randomness - you never know what weird creature will come up next, how you will make it react and how it will react. In the end, however, it's not just pure "let's make everything totally crazy and random cuz that's cool"-randomness which one easily sees through; no, here pretty much everything fits together in this whimsical little world and you get the feeling that there must be something in the Czech culture that inspired to something that feels so odd and magical to us non-Czechs...I dunno.I guess one more aspect that makes this game so interesting is the simple fact that it's a world full of little animals and I for one was reminded of childhood days with adventurous atmosphere, catching little animals out of a pond and studying them and so on.But all of this would not make it a good game if it wasn't for the wonderful graphics and sound design which also fit together perfectly. There is so much funny voice acting going on, so many eerie tunes (think Animal Collective + The Polyphonic Spree + chipmunks rubbing their butts over green grass) and the unique organic look of everything - it's just too much.Sorry if I sound like a child♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on by a fairy but I just totally loved playing this ^^Of course, there are some flaws, like the simple gameplay, the shortness ( I WANT MOOOAR!), but what the heck - if you want perfectly polished games, go play EA stuff...this is one for the heart :}I'd even put it into my list of all-time-favorite games.However, I'm sure many wouldn't like it at all. Guess you'll just have to figure it out yourself ;)9/10PS: Sorry, this was long :P

Posted: November 10, 2012
												Botanicula is a cute and (almost darkly) atmospheric point-and-click adventure game about little plant creatures following out a mythic quest. (Each of the cute little fellows has their own abilities to help overcome the challenges they encounter, though unfortunately they don't come into play more than a few times :/ Oh well, having a whole group of critters with you is still fun.)Botanicula is not your usual point-and-click, where you pixel hunt to progress. Instead you'll be searching around for all the cool little creatures that inhabit the world, simply because you *want* to. Seeing them move around and interact (and all the sounds they make!) is really enjoyable, even more so because of how completely optional it is.Neither will you have to worry about obtuse item combinations to proceed; quest items usually simply frame areas that you'll be exploring, without actually being difficult to collect. The primary difficulty/annoyance comes in the latter half of the game where there are multiple puzzles available at once and you're not sure in what order to do them. Your map is usually good (stylized line drawings on leaves!), although one area in the latter half of the game (the city) is just too jumbled (it's hard to tell where you've been and what's where).Overall, Botanicula is a great little game (~4 hours, if you explore like I do) with excellent art design, sound design, music, and atmosphere. The first half of the game is particularly good, because of its focus on the environment (both on the natural home of the critters and what's happening to it...); the latter half sort of breaks down on that with one area too cluttered (and discordant with the prior environments) and another too spread out, both too unfocused.I certainly enjoyed it, though, and I definitely recommend it (though for me the current $10 tag is a bit much; I got it on a Steam sale a while ago - but if you have money, throw it Amanita for me, ok? :P).Botanicula's certainly a game focused on aesthetics rather than gameplay, and I do love those.

Posted: August 24, 2013
												Botanicula is a nice point-and-click adventure with both puzzle elements and mini games to change the pace. This game can feel like certain chapters take forever and you're likely to find yourself lost if you don't have a way to keep track of where you've been and what you've seen (or a walkthrough from someone who cleared the game) but leading this misfit band on their journey is well worth it to play out the story.

Posted: May 8, 2012
												If you enjoy point-and-click puzzle/adventure games and/or other games from Amanita Designs, you need to own this game -now-. The artwork is lush, the soundtrack is enjoyable and incredibly layered, and despite no written or spoken dialogue (par for the course for Amanita games), you get an in-depth sense of character from both the protagonists and the enemies through clever animation and sound effects. Some of the puzzles can be very devious and you'll find yourself clicking -everything- in hopes of collecting another card. However, I never found that to feel tedious or boring, as the atmosphere was so intensely charming that I enjoyed every minute of gameplay.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												Insect-themed animation bliss.Botanicula brings back the tightly-focused whimsy of Samorost and Machinarium, but unlike this studio's previous titles, it tells a story that is more about a cast of characters than a place. The most wonderful part of Botanicula is the group of unusual critters whom the player controls. Their animations convey so much character, you sometimes forget you've never heard them speak.Botanicula is a very quick game, but like Machinarium and Samorost 1 and 2, it's gorgeous, tightly themed, and challenging without being frustrating. It's good for pretty much any audience-- including non-gamers-- and has a beautiful soundtrack, too. Very highly recommended.

Posted: February 18, 2015
												This is a must for puzzle solving adventure game fans. I was sad when I'd completed it as I was so absorbed in the game I didn't realise how much time had passed. It's so beautiful. It filled me with child-like wonder yet sometimes I felt slightly fearful. The narrative is very simple but you never know what's going to happen next. I love that it was constantly surprising me as a player, in playful & quirky way. I loved how the landscape & characters were almost abstract. The game is simple, with few explanations, so you can invent your own backstory. It almost has paved a new way for puzzle solving 'langauge' in terms of the use of physics & sound in order to solve it. Puzzle games are my favourite and this stumped me quite a lot, as I was thinking about how it would be solved in other adventure games. It was excellent at throwing me off what I thought I had to do it. It was frustrating at certain times but it's great when you figure it out finally.  Overall this was an amazing game & I can't wait to see what this company does next.

Posted: March 1, 2015
												I recommend this game with a small caveat: it really is best for kids.  It is a very cute point-and-click adventure with no possibility of death.  You play as five little plant-like characters exploring a large tree.  I had a three-year-old boy playtest this, and he loved counting the things he found and the pretty pictures.  I have to admit that a few (very few) of the puzzles have stumped me, so he couldn't play it all by himself, and he is fairly smart for a three-year-old.  He made very clear to me that he did not care much for the villainous spiders in the game, but I think that was the point.  For children ages 5-10, I think this is a real treat.  Adults may find it to be too simple.  10/10 for kids.  7/10 for adults.

Posted: August 13, 2015
												Pros*Great visual design and animation. Great music and the atmosphere and non-verbal story-telling is really cool, similar to Machinarium (same devs) as far as characters speaking through picture speech bubbles. I like the contrast of the very vibrant, colorful, livid, lively, green environment and some parts where it's dying and a part close to the end when things get a bit dark, but no very heavy.*Would probably be great for children *Can run on very low-end computersCons*There are only a couple things that were really puzzles. Mostly I was just clicking a bunch of stuff watching all kinds of weird (yet entertaining) things happen before it gave me whatever item I needed to proceed at the time. *It's very abstract (which I like) and not really as much of a little world that Machinarium was, having really randomness to the different places and organisms you meet. Which I think Machinarium is a better game overall, telling a more cohesive narrative versus this game's sort of child drawing story (that could be taken as a negative or a positive). *The game was really short. I have 2.7 hours on this game and that was with clicking on everything I could find, though I didn't quite 100% it but I wasn't far off. I had little to no problem with the "puzzles" so I went through it pretty fast but even someone getting stuck a lot, if that's even possible, would still beat it fairly quickly. I think $10 is a bit pricey for a game that has little replay value and is so short. In summary, this was an enjoyable experience especially at first glance at how wildly out there it was. It's a very sort kid's dream and occasionally nightmare with how abstract it is. But it was very short. I liked Machinarium more.

Posted: April 13, 2015
												Botanicula is amazing. Amanita really outdid themselves with this one. The game is beautiful and detailed, and at the same time elegant and simple. It's cute, it's funny, but it's also quite pretty. And they manage to tell an interesting and entertaining story without a single line of dialog (spoken or written). Yes, the puzzles are noticeably easier than they were in Machinarium, but I feel like the puzzles aren't the point of the game. Rather, your goal is to explore this wonderful and whimsical world of cute little plant and bug creatures, all while trying to save their home from an encroaching monster. To really get the most out of Botanicula, I strongly encourage you to scour every nook and cranny of the world, because there is always something special to be found. I'd recommend this game to anyone who likes simple, yet gorgeously-rendered puzzle games and point-and-click adventures.

Posted: April 12, 2015
												Materially, this is just a simple point-and-click adventure. It does not open up any new frontiers and it will not burn your brain attempting to solve the puzzles. If you are looking for a deep gaming experience, look elsewhere.This game will appeal to people who appreciate the idea of games-as-art; not necessarily deep commentaries that "have something to say" about social issues, but rather just as works of reflection, crafted by a creator who actually cares about the work he is producing. This game is ugly and beautiful at the same time, strangely compelling in its own way, and I felt rewarded when I had completed it. Not really for the sake of the game's story (rudimentary and nebulous at best), but for the sake of having experienced something that I knew came directly from the mind of another human being to my own. That, to me, is what "Art with a capital A" is supposed to be.If the thing I've described above is what you want to see more of in "indie" game design, then spend a couple bucks on this and I think you will be happy.

You'll be tasked to find a yellow blob's missing eye, to rescue an ostrich from being dinner for a family of four, to race a ladybug during a quest to win a prize helmet, and far more. Posted: February 10, 2015
												+ Immensely charming+ Beautiful art style and music+ A few puzzles make you scratch your head- Fairly short (~3 hours for a complete run)Amanita Design bring us yet another point & click/puzzle game in the form of Botanicula, a very cute and charming story of 5 friends trying save the tree on which they live from a menacing corruption. Along the ride one must solve puzzles using the different abilities of the 5 characters.The main strength of the game is how beautiful the art is. Everything seems hand-drawn and the animations reflect that, sometimes making movements very cut-out-ish. The music and the sound effects both complement that with very natural sounding tunes (as in involving individual sounds and hums rather than just musical instruments) and cute sounds from the environment (for example, when many different-sized bugs start humming a specific sound, the largest ones obviously humming in deep basses).The puzzles are relatively simple on average, yet some of the later ones prove to be more complicated than you might imagine for what may strike one as a kid's game. What is unique about Botanicula's puzzles is that it is fun to see what will happen if you click on the wrong character. One problem that I have with the characters though, is that they seem like one entity, meaning it is hard to differentiate them based on their personalities.This brings me on to how short the game is. It arguably contains 5 areas, each one longer than the one before it (which makes sense because you are moving your way down the tree, where the branches are progressively longer). The objective is to pass an obstacle blocking your passage to the next area by solving puzzles in the current area. There are many optional puzzles and things to click on which add to the completion rate on a playthrough, which does give access to additional content near the end based on how high it is. Even with that the game feels like one that should be completed in one playthrough, and, just like most point & clicks, there is no replay value in the game unless one did not achieve 100% completion.All in all, Botanicula offers a short, but very charming and beautifully simple experience. Its simplicity can be both an upside and, at times, a downside.

Posted: February 14, 2015
Botanicula is a beautiful and whimsical point-and-click adventure. While very bright and cheery, it, much like Machinarium, is also somewhat dark. That (sometimes literal) contrast creates an extremely entertaining atmosphere and a cute story. It does have it's negatives though, the game can often become frustrating and tedious because of a lack of indication within the game of what to do. This is really just a problem inherent to the genre of point-and-click games, and for the most part Botanicula is better at avoiding this than other games. Only once during the entire game did I have to check a walkthrough out of frustration. Overall, great game.Graphics: 10/10Mechanics: 7/10Performance: 9/10Story: 10/10Fun-factor: 8/10Overall score: 8.5/10A must play for any fan of the point-and-click genre.

Posted: February 18, 2015
												This is a must for puzzle solving adventure game fans. I was sad when I'd completed it as I was so absorbed in the game I didn't realise how much time had passed. It's so beautiful. It filled me with child-like wonder yet sometimes I felt slightly fearful. The narrative is very simple but you never know what's going to happen next. I love that it was constantly surprising me as a player, in playful & quirky way. I loved how the landscape & characters were almost abstract. The game is simple, with few explanations, so you can invent your own backstory. It almost has paved a new way for puzzle solving 'langauge' in terms of the use of physics & sound in order to solve it. Puzzle games are my favourite and this stumped me quite a lot, as I was thinking about how it would be solved in other adventure games. It was excellent at throwing me off what I thought I had to do it. It was frustrating at certain times but it's great when you figure it out finally.  Overall this was an amazing game & I can't wait to see what this company does next.

Posted: September 4, 2013
												One of my favourite games and possibly the most enjoyable in the point and click adventure genre. Everything has been designed so beautifully (in ways words cannot describe). Its visually stunning, the characters are funny, memorable and loveable and the soundtrack is amazing. The levels/ environments are fluid, organic and interesting (you'll be clicking on everything). You are rewarded with animated collectable character & creature cards for exploring the world and interacting with stuff... and you won't get bored of seeing the same things over and over, as the surroundings change at nearly every screen. The diversity is truly astounding. The pace of the game is good too, meaning you are not stuck at the same screen trying to solve a puzzle for ages, but not moving so quick as to miss the hidden gems and soak in the scenery. To contrast the beautiful lively 'spring-like' levels, there are also darker and more isolated spaces, which relate to the story. The story is simple yet brilliant, and it is told in an interesting way without even uttering a word. It's one of those games that's fairly challenging at times but without being too frustrating. The puzzles are enjoyable and make me laugh, rather than them feeling like a chore to complete. It certainly makes me smile... and at many points its just so beautiful and amazing, it might just make you all teary eyed with sheer joy.  :)I honestly can't find anything wrong with this game... it really is a wonderful experience. Would highly reccomend. The game is by Amanita design, and I bought it in the Amanita Bundle with Samorost 2 and Machinarium, two other masterpieces to play through.   :)  - 10/10 -

Posted: January 4, 2015
												This is a short little game -under 3 hours on my first run- that despite its length makes for a lovely treat on those days you want to escape from reality in a relaxed atmosphere. The creatures and environments are beautiful, the soundtrack and voices are so nice, that even when the story line is slightly creepy (a bunch of spider-like creatures are threatening the inhabitants of the Botanicula tree and a couple of seeds must do the saving) even the darkest episodes are full of charm and good vibes.The game is a point and click with not much difficulty. Most of the puzzles can be solved with a little logic or even by simply trying what you can click on. To unlock all secrets and Steam achievements, some more skill-luck-persistence will be required (I am actually stuck with the Svolavac one; I know what I´m supposed to do but I havent found the right combo yet).I enjoyed the game so much that I re-started it just to see if I could get all the achievements. I´ve gone through it 3 times now and have only used hints for Svolavac, but I have taken longer on the 2 later runs because I am taking my time enjoying the scenery and soundtrack, the humorous interactions and the frog concert.I would recommend this game to anyone who likes original design, to anyone who appreciates audio-visual artwork, to anyone who likes plants and insects, point and click games or to anone who is simply looking for a unique and stress-less game.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												+ Immensely charming+ Beautiful art style and music+ A few puzzles make you scratch your head- Fairly short (~3 hours for a complete run)Amanita Design bring us yet another point & click/puzzle game in the form of Botanicula, a very cute and charming story of 5 friends trying save the tree on which they live from a menacing corruption. Along the ride one must solve puzzles using the different abilities of the 5 characters.The main strength of the game is how beautiful the art is. Everything seems hand-drawn and the animations reflect that, sometimes making movements very cut-out-ish. The music and the sound effects both complement that with very natural sounding tunes (as in involving individual sounds and hums rather than just musical instruments) and cute sounds from the environment (for example, when many different-sized bugs start humming a specific sound, the largest ones obviously humming in deep basses).The puzzles are relatively simple on average, yet some of the later ones prove to be more complicated than you might imagine for what may strike one as a kid's game. What is unique about Botanicula's puzzles is that it is fun to see what will happen if you click on the wrong character. One problem that I have with the characters though, is that they seem like one entity, meaning it is hard to differentiate them based on their personalities.This brings me on to how short the game is. It arguably contains 5 areas, each one longer than the one before it (which makes sense because you are moving your way down the tree, where the branches are progressively longer). The objective is to pass an obstacle blocking your passage to the next area by solving puzzles in the current area. There are many optional puzzles and things to click on which add to the completion rate on a playthrough, which does give access to additional content near the end based on how high it is. Even with that the game feels like one that should be completed in one playthrough, and, just like most point & clicks, there is no replay value in the game unless one did not achieve 100% completion.All in all, Botanicula offers a short, but very charming and beautifully simple experience. Its simplicity can be both an upside and, at times, a downside.

Posted: August 28, 2013
												A game that has and needs no words. You are the inhabitants of a large tree that is the home of around fifty species of insect. However a terrible evil is taking hold of the vegetation and draining its roots leaving only despair. A team of brave insects assemble to adventure down into the depths of the tree and into the belly of the beast, solving puzzles along the way. Rather than playing as a single character, you are descending the tree as the whole group of creatures, choosing different characters to complete different puzzles until you reach your goal.Despite the dark nature of the story, the game handles it well delivering a feel good experience. Just about all the sound effects in the game are made by the human voice, with a few pieces of percussion filling the gaps. Each area has its own theme and some areas have a friendly sort of warmth made up by the scenery and soundtrack. As much as this game is more important than life itself, breaks in gameplay would be advised, since the objectives do get tedious after a little while of hunting for the next meaningful object that you need to fetch for the little munchkins who are not proactive enough to get for themselves. The most memorable one is the mission to hunt down fourteen small ostriches to pedal the turbines to make a huge hot air balloon float of into the air, so a species of hairy-looking creatures can escape to the skies. All in all though, it’s a beautiful game visually and soundwise which I would rate very highly indeed.

Posted: May 7, 2012
												After finishing this game, I wanted to run out and plant a tree.  Seriously, though, this game is absolutely beautiful.  The character design is original and adorable.  The soundtrack and sound effects -- all done by the two people who make up DVA -- are perfect, and add to the naturalistic atmosphere of the game wonderfully.  The setting itself is fantastic and imaginative, with its little secrets and delights to discover.  You cannot imagine my reaction when the giant turtle revealed itself (you know the part if you've seen it), or when the lightning bugs land on the vines in the area under the frogs and crabs (again, you'll know the part when you see it).  The game also balances humor and terror very nicely.  The dream sequences are some of the creepiest game scenes I've ever seen, and the Zlos themselves are their own lovely brand of horror.  In short, this game was worth the price I paid for it.  20/10, would play again.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												Insect-themed animation bliss.Botanicula brings back the tightly-focused whimsy of Samorost and Machinarium, but unlike this studio's previous titles, it tells a story that is more about a cast of characters than a place. The most wonderful part of Botanicula is the group of unusual critters whom the player controls. Their animations convey so much character, you sometimes forget you've never heard them speak.Botanicula is a very quick game, but like Machinarium and Samorost 1 and 2, it's gorgeous, tightly themed, and challenging without being frustrating. It's good for pretty much any audience-- including non-gamers-- and has a beautiful soundtrack, too. Very highly recommended.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												This is definitely one of the most psychadelicly creative games I have ever played. You play as five charcters at once, and they are, as far as I can tell, a nut, a big nut, a stick, a mushroom, and a gnat. Each has unique abilities that are used sometimes to solve puzzles, although this mostly comes into play in the beginning of the game. The level and art design are superb and pretty much every puzzle I solved was a delight. There were a few moments where the puzzle design was tedious, but that happens with pretty much every adventure-type game like this. For the most part, the items you get have obvious uses and you don't have a giant inventory of items that you have to try in different combinations to find the solution. Most of the puzzle solving is based on clicking on the environment and moving your mouse to affect it. Your mouse movements affect the environement in this game (making the flowers move in the breeze, etc.) and this mechanic is often used for puzzle solving. I highly recommend this game!

Posted: December 23, 2013
												       I will preface this review with this; this game is not for everone, if you enjoy constant action, verbal schematics and a gutteral experience, you will most likely not enjoy this game.       Botanicula is a point-and-click game developed by Amanita design who are most famous for Machinarium (which I also highly suggest.) The game, in terms of mechanics, is very similar to Machinarium but is more adventure centric, with most puzzles revolving around walking around the environment and finding what looks out of place. But the atmosphere is definitely this game's strong suit. You play as a bunch of seed-like creatures who have formed an alliance to save the tree that they live on. The story is very vague, all that is shown is a viral, black creature that begins to dismantle the tree. There is no dialogue in this game, this does not hinder the game though, the game has a way of telling you everything that you need to know without actually telling you anything, and you find yourself growing attached to the seemingly one-dimensional seed people and their goals and aspirations.       This game just oozes with pure, ethereal, joy with it's soundtrack composed of home-made instruments, and the adorable characters, and the gorgeous visuals. There's just something so special about finding an inhabitant of the tree and solving one of their problems in exchange for a pot to complete a puzzle that's just so satisfying.       I am not going to confine this game to a simple rating, it cannot be impartially analyzed due to it now being so ingrained into me with all of it's charm, all I can do is recommend that you take a look at it.

Posted: May 7, 2012
												Botanicula is a short point and click adventure game from the developers of Machinarium and Samorost 1 and 2, Amanita Design. The game lasts about six to seven hours (getting all achievements and such), all of which are amazing. Every interaction is full of life, emotion, and uniqueness - resulting in characters with more personality than ones in most AAA games. The characters and story rival those, if not exceed, of Machinarium's. Only "flaw" with the game is there are no puzzles or much challenge, and thus no real gameplay. This takes away any real replay value.Only thing Botanicula can offer is character. Fortunately that's all you really need with this game.Edit: I take back the AAA dig - it's unfair. This game has more personality than a lot of indie games too.

Posted: January 4, 2013
												Oh noes, it's over already :(I should have picked this one up immediately when it came out; the design told me so. The reason I didn't - I guess - was (apart from me hoping it would be in an indie bundle) that I couldn't imagine how gameplay would fit into this when I saw the trailer. And to be honest, the game doesn't exactly score with its gameplay mechanics; they have something browser-gamerish, even almost dilettant about them. But really, I couldn't care less. Because no game since... actually I cannot even think of any right now that ensorcelled (does that word really exist? O_o) me in such a way as this one (of course some other games à la Final Fantasy VII captivated me in very different ways). How does this game manage to do this? With its apparant randomness - you never know what weird creature will come up next, how you will make it react and how it will react. In the end, however, it's not just pure "let's make everything totally crazy and random cuz that's cool"-randomness which one easily sees through; no, here pretty much everything fits together in this whimsical little world and you get the feeling that there must be something in the Czech culture that inspired to something that feels so odd and magical to us non-Czechs...I dunno.I guess one more aspect that makes this game so interesting is the simple fact that it's a world full of little animals and I for one was reminded of childhood days with adventurous atmosphere, catching little animals out of a pond and studying them and so on.But all of this would not make it a good game if it wasn't for the wonderful graphics and sound design which also fit together perfectly. There is so much funny voice acting going on, so many eerie tunes (think Animal Collective + The Polyphonic Spree + chipmunks rubbing their butts over green grass) and the unique organic look of everything - it's just too much.Sorry if I sound like a child♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on by a fairy but I just totally loved playing this ^^Of course, there are some flaws, like the simple gameplay, the shortness ( I WANT MOOOAR!), but what the heck - if you want perfectly polished games, go play EA stuff...this is one for the heart :}I'd even put it into my list of all-time-favorite games.However, I'm sure many wouldn't like it at all. Guess you'll just have to figure it out yourself ;)9/10PS: Sorry, this was long :P

Posted: October 31, 2012
												Botanicula is a very simple point-and-click adventure game that uses minimalistic gestures, visuals, and sounds to guide the player on a tale filled with humor, playfulness, and, most of all, discovery.  Every new area holds a new creature or vegetable that manages to be both cute and mysterious.There are very few games that can convey the simple and undiluted joy of discovering new things.  Botanicula is one of them, and does it all with zero dialogue.  Most of my first playthrough found me smiling gleefully as the five protagonists enthusiastically escaped the treacherous claws of the sinister shadow spider.Botanicula is a short little game about a short little story that follows the example of Dr. Seuss and Shel Silverstein, and at only an hour or two of playtime, it never wears out its welcome.  It is an adorable journey that left me feeling like a child again.  There's a great, big, wonderful world out there full of adventures, and this game made me remember it.

												An endearing point-and-click game with a story told completely (and wonderfully) through visuals. Sometimes the puzzles can be a little tricky and there were a few times where I got stuck and had to look up a walkthrough, but for the most part just exploring and examining things led me to the correct answers. I actually laughed out loud at multiple points when a new creature appeared or when an event in the game happened.I love this game and heartily recommend it to anyone who enjoys point-and-click adventure games, anyone who likes things that are different from main-stream, anyone who likes exploring game worlds and finding all the hidden secrets, and everyone else.

Posted: August 13, 2015
												Pros*Great visual design and animation. Great music and the atmosphere and non-verbal story-telling is really cool, similar to Machinarium (same devs) as far as characters speaking through picture speech bubbles. I like the contrast of the very vibrant, colorful, livid, lively, green environment and some parts where it's dying and a part close to the end when things get a bit dark, but no very heavy.*Would probably be great for children *Can run on very low-end computersCons*There are only a couple things that were really puzzles. Mostly I was just clicking a bunch of stuff watching all kinds of weird (yet entertaining) things happen before it gave me whatever item I needed to proceed at the time. *It's very abstract (which I like) and not really as much of a little world that Machinarium was, having really randomness to the different places and organisms you meet. Which I think Machinarium is a better game overall, telling a more cohesive narrative versus this game's sort of child drawing story (that could be taken as a negative or a positive). *The game was really short. I have 2.7 hours on this game and that was with clicking on everything I could find, though I didn't quite 100% it but I wasn't far off. I had little to no problem with the "puzzles" so I went through it pretty fast but even someone getting stuck a lot, if that's even possible, would still beat it fairly quickly. I think $10 is a bit pricey for a game that has little replay value and is so short. In summary, this was an enjoyable experience especially at first glance at how wildly out there it was. It's a very sort kid's dream and occasionally nightmare with how abstract it is. But it was very short. I liked Machinarium more.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												I know I've said this about Amanita Design in another review, but their games are stunningly beautiful. They have managed to create a world all of its own; which drags the player in with its wonder, scope, and beauty. I am writing this review shortly after completing the game and feel the need to go back to find more of the secrets and to 100% it. This game is a point and click adventure with minimalistic story-telling. It features puzzle-solving some of which are simple, others of which take a bit more pathfinding. Musically speaking it works, the pieces reflect the atmosphere of the game well and can give the player the sense of the mood of the game. I found at some points of the game the music to be very engaging and would sit on certain screens just to listen. This game took me a little over three hours to beat. I would say its about 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 hours long depending on player, and is worth a replay eventually. The price of this game is fair.

												First off,  if you don't particularily like short games or games without speaking or subtitles, you may not like this game. Posted: January 3, 2016
												I just took the weekend for 2 of Amanita's games: Machinarium and Botanicula.If you've ever played Machinarium before (and you liked it), I'm telling you now that Botanicula is just as amazing. Get it, play it, enjoy it! The graphics are lighter and more colourful in general, the puzzles are only a little less challenging (so no need for a "cheating" notebook on the upper right corner, but you still need to crack your head every once in a while), and the story is just as adorable.If you haven't played any of this studio's games, however, allow me to summarise without spoiling you: Botanicula tells the story of a group of plant-y friends who embark on a journey to save the tree of light from darkness (embodied by spiders). Since it's a puzzle game, you need to complete several tasks to get items and continue to the next level. You will find a total of 123 creatures, each representing a creature card that will be given to you, and which you can look at by selecting the deck on the upper left corner. Take your time, though! There are plenty of Easter eggs along the way (golden cards, and also your Steam achievements) that don't all need to be found for you to go through to the end.100% recommend if you're into logic and thinking while having fun.I personally loved it.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												A funny, imaginative, and fun-to-play point & click adventure game about five little animal/plant friends on a journey to save their home from cruel, energy-sapping spiders. Another stunning work from Amanita, even topping their previous effort, Machinarium. Puzzles have a great difficulty curve, the art and music are beautiful, and the narrative is simple and emotionally compelling. Since there's so much to discover (see the achievements), there's a reason to replay after your first time through, as well. I love this game.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												I love this game! Visually rich, with incredible artwork, and puzzles that are so layered and complex I would never have gotten past the first level without a detailed walkthrough. I'm sure that after completing the game I have forgotten most of what I should have learned, and much remains undiscovered. A lot of guesswork is involved despite the many visual and auditory clues, as well as a certain amount of manual dexterity. I like the fact that a player can stop as often as necessary, go back, and try again without forfeiting the progress already made. I will definitely play this one again. For $3.99, Botanicula was a real bargain. Very unique, I've never seen anything quite like it.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												A disappointingly short game, but only because it was so enjoyable.  The artwork and sound effects were amazing and it seemed like I was actually entering another world.  The myriad of colors, textures, animations, flora and fauna were staggering.  Overall the story was quite good and all the characters entertaining.  I found the main tasks/puzzles to be fairly easy, which kept the story enjoyable, and the bonus cards required a bit more deduction.  A good balance in my opinion.If you are looking for a quality point-and-click adventure, this game is top notch.  Just don't expect Myst-like difficulty.

Posted: October 31, 2012
												Botanicula is a very simple point-and-click adventure game that uses minimalistic gestures, visuals, and sounds to guide the player on a tale filled with humor, playfulness, and, most of all, discovery.  Every new area holds a new creature or vegetable that manages to be both cute and mysterious.There are very few games that can convey the simple and undiluted joy of discovering new things.  Botanicula is one of them, and does it all with zero dialogue.  Most of my first playthrough found me smiling gleefully as the five protagonists enthusiastically escaped the treacherous claws of the sinister shadow spider.Botanicula is a short little game about a short little story that follows the example of Dr. Seuss and Shel Silverstein, and at only an hour or two of playtime, it never wears out its welcome.  It is an adorable journey that left me feeling like a child again.  There's a great, big, wonderful world out there full of adventures, and this game made me remember it.

Posted: February 14, 2015
Botanicula is a beautiful and whimsical point-and-click adventure. While very bright and cheery, it, much like Machinarium, is also somewhat dark. That (sometimes literal) contrast creates an extremely entertaining atmosphere and a cute story. It does have it's negatives though, the game can often become frustrating and tedious because of a lack of indication within the game of what to do. This is really just a problem inherent to the genre of point-and-click games, and for the most part Botanicula is better at avoiding this than other games. Only once during the entire game did I have to check a walkthrough out of frustration. Overall, great game.Graphics: 10/10Mechanics: 7/10Performance: 9/10Story: 10/10Fun-factor: 8/10Overall score: 8.5/10A must play for any fan of the point-and-click genre.

Posted: February 18, 2015
												This is a must for puzzle solving adventure game fans. I was sad when I'd completed it as I was so absorbed in the game I didn't realise how much time had passed. It's so beautiful. It filled me with child-like wonder yet sometimes I felt slightly fearful. The narrative is very simple but you never know what's going to happen next. I love that it was constantly surprising me as a player, in playful & quirky way. I loved how the landscape & characters were almost abstract. The game is simple, with few explanations, so you can invent your own backstory. It almost has paved a new way for puzzle solving 'langauge' in terms of the use of physics & sound in order to solve it. Puzzle games are my favourite and this stumped me quite a lot, as I was thinking about how it would be solved in other adventure games. It was excellent at throwing me off what I thought I had to do it. It was frustrating at certain times but it's great when you figure it out finally.  Overall this was an amazing game & I can't wait to see what this company does next.

Posted: May 25, 2013
												Botanicula absolutely explodes with creativity. Every new area is a treat for the eyes, and the myriad creatures your posse encounters are each uniquely designed and characterized. There are a host of mini-puzzles to solve, and many of the tree-creatures have small objectives for you to accomplish. You'll be tasked to find a yellow blob's missing eye, to rescue an ostrich from being dinner for a family of four, to race a ladybug during a quest to win a prize helmet, and far more. The amount of originality in Botanicula is stunning, and there's even a Machinarium cameo for Amanita fans. As the game is only a few hours long, it's a delightful experience that shouldn't be missed.

On the other hand, there are a few puzzles where there is too much trial and error going on, where you just click things and hope it works. Still, I really like the overall feel, and think that in a sale it's worth the price. Most solutions are genuinely cute and give you a nice animation of the resolve. Posted: December 26, 2016
												At first when I purchased Botanicula, I wasn't too sure I would like it. Truth be told, I only bought it because the characters and art style looked super cute. I never really had any experience with point-and-click games - at least not in a long while - so this purchase was something of a risk for me. But, every risk has the possibility of becoming a sweetass reward, and, now that I've beaten the game, I can definitely consider my purchase of Botanicula to be just that. As I've mentioned, the characters and art style are super cute, and they surely have enough charm to match its cuteness. I couldn't stop smiling and giggling throughout my 6 hour playthrough due to the oodles and oodles of OMGEVERYTHINGISSOCUTENESS. Like, if you wanna see what I'm talking about, watch this 27 second YouTube video I made of some singing frogs from the game: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jLo49T7z-JwSo, yeah: The game's as cute as a bug, and considering I have, like, 87 mental disorders involving the symptom depression, that's pretty important to me. But, what's also important to me is for there to be some sort of meaning to the game. Like, why are these bugs just going around talking to singing frogs and solving puzzles (more on the puzzles in a moment)? Well, the game does a really good job of explaining its story in a way that provides empathy for the characters' plight without using words to do so. Like, the game doesn't use any words at all. Everything is expressed using imagery and emotional gibberish; it's adorable and heart-touching at the same time. By the end of the game, I was so determined to help the buggos, that I didn't mind failing at puzzles again and again and again - so long as I knew that eventually I'd perservere, and Mr. Twig and his buddies would eventually be happy again!The puzzles themselves are, well, they're certainly satisfying to solve! Just about every time you solve a puzzle, the characters go all "YooHoo!" and it's THE CUTEST THING EVER OMG! I'm normally pretty terrible at puzzles (I blame those aforementioned mental disorders), so I eventually needed a guide to help me through the game. However, one thing I did notice was that it was also pretty difficult to identify where exactly puzzles were supposed to be. Like, not just what you were supposed to do in a puzzle, but what exactly was a puzzle? Where to start a puzzle? Sometimes it was tough to just get started, and I feel like this might be a problem for more people than just myself, especially near the end of the game. There's this awfully mazy-like area, and it practically forces you to use a guide for at least some of it. For me this wasn't a really big deal, since I didn't really buy this game for its puzzles anyway, but I could definitely see some people becoming upset by this. So, there ya have it: my feelings about this game. I'm sure you're all very scared now by all of this, but you shouldn't be scared of purchasing this game, at least not if you like cute things and puzzles. Very, very, very nice game, and I'm looking forward to playing the other games done by Amanita Design.<3Pros:- Incredibly charming in every aspect possible- Clever storytelling that doesn't rely on words - Atmospheric soundtrack and sound effects- Interactive environment- Puzzles are generally satisfying to solveCons:- Easy to get lost- Puzzles are a little too difficult to identify sometimes

Posted: September 17, 2012
												Beautiful adventure game in the life of 5 lovable characters who are trying to save their tree from scary parasites.That's the short version. The long version, this is a wonderful, quirky, gorgeous, hilarious adventure that gets quite creepy later on. The main characters are cute and endearing, the story light (without words) but still poignant, the evil spider-like creatures menacing. The puzzles are just challenging enough to be enjoyable without being frustrating. Highly recommended to anyone who loves a good adventure game.

Posted: January 9
												I'm not normally a fan of point and click games but Amanita's releases and in particular Botanicula have really drawn me into the genre.Basically, you control a team of plants/creatures who are trying to protect their home from invaders. The story is indirect but heartwarming and enjoyable. I found myself replaying the game several times to find the collectables and each time I found myself appreciating everything a lot more, particularly the soundtrack.The game oozes  with loving craft from the developers and left me wanting more. It also made me check out and appreciate both Samarost games and Machinarium, also from Amanita.If unsure, grab it on sale, well worth it if you like story driven single player experiences as I do. A great game.

Posted: January 5
												Full of imagination! You feel like you're part of an important journey, and that there is something deeper about life locked away in here. Full of good puzzles and some laughs. A charming couple of hours for sure :)

Posted: January 7
												I will review all my humble bundle games and see which is worth playing and which is not! Like a lot of people i buy H.B. games as a pack because i want some of the games, but not all. I will play for 5 minutes (or a litlle bit more) and give you my opinion on it. Sometimes the game will surprise me, sometimes it will be a total dissapointment. Just keep in mind this is my opinion only and is not an objective view of the game. You might actually like it!The review will be constructed into 5 parts:1. Game description (from what i've seen in the time i've played).2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.3. Pros/Cons.4. Final thoughts.5. RatingSo let's beggin...1. Game description:Point and click adventure at it’s finest. The team behind Machinarium did not disappoint. I don’t want to spoil anything, let’s just say that without saying a word this game tells a better story than a lot of other games. The atmosphere is brilliant. The sound and music mixes with the actions you take and on every screen there is something that you can do, even if it is not quest related. 2. Did i finish the game? YESThe game is fairly short if you know what you are doing, however if you take your time to explore the environment and find all the hidden stuff it will take you a while. I will come back to this game one day to find the last hidden creature.3. Pros/Cons.PROS:- Beutiful visuals- Superb sound and music- Interesting story- Tons of hidden stuff to find and exploreCONS:- None4. Final thoughts:Just get it! You won’t be disappointed. Again HB manages to throw in a game that blows me away. This is one of those games you come home to after a hard day at work. Just sit down relax and get absorbed in the story and atmosphere. 5. Rating10/10

Posted: February 25
												This is just AMAZING. A simple point and click game - But it just has so much charm to it that you can't help but love it. The cute characters and easy-to-follow plotlines is a great plus point, and the flow of the game is just so smooth and easy, definitely a must play if you like a casual game. The music is just another wonder entirely, I love it. It complements the game so well, and you'll just sort of find yourself immersed into the game while you listen to the music. Though it's simple and short, the beauty of this game is undeniable. 10/10 would recommend.

Posted: April 16
												A simple point and click game with lovely soundtrack, a simplistic and easy to follow story, and lots of humorous moments. I have replayed this game many times, and owned it before I bought it again on Steam. Well worth the price, and full of surprises that make you want to click every leaf to make sure you haven't missed anything.

Posted: February 24
												Point and click adventure that feels like a perfect blend between Monty Python and a clever French animated show called Miniscule. That should give you and general idea of whether you will like it or not.Puzzles are mostly the right kind of challenging, the soundtrack and especially sound effects are incredible, and the quirky story kept me engaged.Well worth a look even at full price but especially on sale.
